statements.text: Force acting on a mass produces acceleration, changing the object's velocity over time.
Velocity describes speed and direction, while acceleration links changing velocity to the net force on mass.
Kinetic energy depends on an object's mass and velocity, increasing rapidly as velocity grows.
Momentum combines mass and velocity, remaining conserved in isolated systems where no external force acts.
Gravitational potential energy increases as an object is lifted against gravity, storing reversible mechanical energy.
Friction opposes motion between surfaces, converting mechanical energy into heat and reducing momentum over time.
In free fall, gravity accelerates a mass downward, converting gravitational potential energy into increasing kinetic energy.
Work transfers energy when a force moves an object, linking force, distance and kinetic energy.
Power measures how quickly work is done, relating transferred energy to the time interval involved.
Balanced forces like friction produce constant velocity, while unbalanced forces create acceleration, changing momentum and mechanical energy.
